data: 2 joining fragments of a marble plaque. Rear is roughly chiselled flat, as are the sides. The plaque was re-used in antiquity for a relief, which rotated the stone through 90 degrees in comparison to the inscription which was previously traced upon the stone. Traces of the inscription are preserved along the right and lower borders of the relief, and at occasional points in the relief where the original surface of the plaque is preserved (as it is on the borders). Consequently much of line 1 is preserved, traces of 2, and ends of another c.8 lines.
Letters are square in module, regular and neat, with faint serifs at the termination of the strokes. Letters are consistently 9 mm high, except for omicron which is 4-5 mm.
Photo J. Prag 03.10.2019: Aut. Assessorato Beni Culturali Regione Siciliana n.10681 del 06/05/2014

An outstanding collection of archaeological material. The collection ranges from Siracusa and the surrounding territory (Megara Hyblaia, Akrai, Kasmenai etc) to encompass all of eastern Sicily, reaching as far as Gela and Agrigento. The ground floor covers prehistory through to the end of the Classical period. Upstairs includes Hellenistic and Roman Syracuse and a display of material from the catacombs. A gallery displaying material from Hellenistic eastern Sicily is in preparation.
L'année épigraphique: revue des publications épigraphiques relatives a l'antiquité romaine.

« L’année épigraphique: revue des publications épigraphiques relatives a l’antiquité romaine. », L’année épigraphique : revue des publications épigraphiques relatives a l’antiquité romaine., 1888, http://www.worldcat.org/oclc/630058599

Fenici, Cartaginesi, Numidi tra i Greci (IV-I sec. a.C.)
Giacomo Manganaro, «Fenici, Cartaginesi, Numidi tra i Greci (IV-I sec. a.C.)», Numismatica e antichità classiche : quaderni ticinesi 29 (2000): 255–69
Le roi Hiempsal II de Numidie et Rhodes

2 joining fragments of a marble plaque. Rear is roughly chiselled flat, as are the sides. The plaque was re-used in antiquity for a relief, which rotated the stone through 90 degrees in comparison to the inscription which was previously traced upon the stone. Traces of the inscription are preserved along the right and lower borders of the relief, and at occasional points in the relief where the original surface of the plaque is preserved (as it is on the borders). Consequently much of line 1 is preserved, traces of 2, and ends of another c.8 lines.

marble plaque 26.9 14.7 2.8 chiselled

Letters are square in module, regular and neat, with faint serifs at the termination of the strokes. Letters are consistently 9 mm high, except for omicron which is 4-5 mm.
